description:
Serpent’s tail, bat’s wing, frog’s leg and owl’s eye... combine the ingredients and be the first to finish making your potion; cast the spells and become the top sorcerer!

Contents
132 cards, that include:

     96 ingredients. Each card has a number between 1 and 4, plus one ingredient.
     12 magic wands
     24 spells


12 special potion cards.

Shuffle the cards and give everyone 3 each, then place the rest in the middle of the table. Pick 3 cards and place them next to the pack together with the 12 special potion cards.

During your turn, carry out the following 2 actions in
sequence:
1) Take 3 cards from the middle of the table. You can draw them from the pack or choose from the revealed ones.
2) Put down a card, placing it next to the revealed cards in the middle of the table.

During your turn, you can also carry out the following 2 additional actions:
1) Cast a spell. Spells allow you to carry out a special action instantly.
2) Make a potion. A potion consists of a combination of 3 or 4 ingredients.
For a combination to be valid, the cards must have the same number and different ingredients or the same ingredients and different numbers. If you made one of the potions in the middle of the table first, take the corresponding special card and place it in front of you. If you have taken a special card with a spell, you should apply the effect
immediately.

When there are no more special cards left in the middle of the table or there are fewer than 3 cards in the pack you are drawing from, the game ends. Count one point for each face-down card in front of you and add the points indicated on the
special cards: whoever has the most points is the winner.

—description from the designer

Choose your team and challenge your opponent.
You will have 5 animal teams and lots of special cards for animated games that keep you on the edge of your seat!

Contents:
132 cards that include:

     5 animal teams made up of 25 cards each. Most of the cards fall within the numerical range of 1 and 11, plus a possible special action. Some cards show a referee.
     1 football pitch made up of 7 cards.


1 ball
12 goal counters

Choose your team and take your pack of 25 cards, then draw 3 cards.
Each player will have a covered card in front of them which must be turned over at exactly the same time that the opponent turns over theirs. The player with the highest card wins the tackle and moves the ball across to the next pitch card. Draw another card from your pile of cards and play again.

If the ball ends up on the pitch card with the penalty box and you win the tackle, the ball goes into the opponent’s goal and you score! Move the ball into a midfield position and start playing again.

On some cards there is a special action. Some examples: move the ball 3 cards forwards, stop the ball, beats 10 and 11.

When all the cards have run out, the first half of the match is over. The match finishes once the second half is over. The player with most goal wins.

—description from the designer

MGMF is a Pro and College American football play-by-play statistical simulation/replay game that uses two different double sided fast action decks of 100 cards each. The game also uses team cards with ratings for all position players in conjunction with the fast action cards to give the results of nearly everything that can happen in a football game.

FAF is a play by play statistical simulation of Pro and college American football implemented by the use of 60 fast action cards and ratings of all offensive skill player positions vs team defensive ratings.

Warcaster: Neo-Mechanika is a high-speed hobby miniatures game for two players who each take on the role of a powerful Warcaster in command of a formidable battle force. Players assemble and customize a force of 20–30 models and fight a scenario-driven battle using dice and cards to control their mighty units and to cast epic cyphers. The game is played using an alternating-activation turn sequence with a round tracker that governs scoring opportunities and the duration of ongoing effects. Players take turns activating units one at a time and using their rack of cyphers, reality-warping spells that can be used to enhance their troops and warjacks or to devastate their opponent’s forces.

While the Warcaster is not physically present on the battlefield, their presence is always felt. A Warcaster coordinates and supports their forces from a sophisticated command and control center called a rack, located aboard a massive battle carrier that transports the Warcaster’s troops and warjacks. In the game, the rack is represented by a deck of cards—the spell-like cyphers—that players customize prior to the game based on the powers and abilities they wish to wield as a Warcaster.

—description from the publisher

Play to reconstruct the timeline of events and put history in order!

From the arrival in Gaul of Clodion the Long-haired (around 430) to the overthrow of Napoleon III (1871), find in this title a selection of 60 sovereigns who have marked the history of France.

Chroni - The Kings and Queens of France is a learning game with which we have fun gradually and durably memorizing the big dates. Ideal for the curious who wish to discover or rediscover History in all or simply or the amateurs who want to consolidate their knowledge.

Chroniis a card game where each card depicts a historical event, invention or discovery on both sides, with the year in which that event occurred, invention or discovery was made on only one side. Players take turns placing a card from their hand in a row on the table. After placing the card, the player reveals the date on it. If the card was placed correctly with the date in chronological order with all other cards on the table, the card stays in place; otherwise the card is removed from play and the player takes another card from the deck.

The first player to get rid of all his cards by placing them correctly wins. If multiple players go out in the same round, then everyone else is eliminated from play and each of those players are dealt one more card for another round of play. If only one player has no cards after a bonus round, he wins; otherwise play continues until a single player goes out.

Re-enact the battles of the American War of Independence in miniature with these wargames rules: Red Feathers & Delaware Blues.

This system gives an enjoyable game of medium length (2-3 hours) that catches the flavour of the American War of Independence. These rules should enable you to fight a battle where the units move and react in a way that is authentic.

Although it is marketed towards 6mm figures, any scale can be used, right up to 28mm.

—description from the publisher

Note: "Delaware Blues" refers to the 1st Delaware Regiment.

literally translated by: whore trick

Players score points by doing dirty tricks in a specific situation by associating cards in their hands. The dirtiest one scores (decided by the current GM player). Rules also change from turn to turn.
Players keep going until one reaches 5 points.

—user summary

Le nouveau jeu by Topito : soyez la pire enflure et remportez la partie !

En associant des cartes " situation ", " personnage ", " action " et " objet ", fomentez le pire coup de pute possible : tous les coups sont permis ! Et n'oubliez pas, même les règles du jeu sont pleines de bassesses, changent à chaque situation pour plus de piment... et risquent de vous surprendre au pire moment !

Cartes Situations :
À l'enterrement de ma mamie...
Règle coup de pute de la situation : chaque joueur donne 2 cartes objet à son voisin de gauche.
C'est le jour de mon mariage...
Règle coup de pute : si un joueur prononce le mot " le ", il reçoit une pichenette.
J'ai une vilaine infection urinaire...
Règle coup de pute : le joueur le plus jeune passe son tour.

Cartes Personnages :
Ton papa chéri, Jean-Luc Mélenchon, un dealer chauve et aveugle, le gentil facteur, ta mère, ton cousin qui a été adopté...

Cartes Objets :
Ton utérus, un ticket de loto gagnant, un buste de Dany Boon, un slip sale, un iPhone neuf, un couteau mal aiguisé

Cartes Actions :
Prendre en bouche, jongler, insérer, passer au four, se moucher dans, gratter...

—description from the publisher

In Hot Tub High Dive by Hasbro Games, players spin the spinner, then press the big red button the number of times shown to send the diver up or down the ladder. Every press of the button increases the amount of foam in the tub. Once the diver reaches the top of the ladder, he will fall into the tub, launching a ball of suds at the unlucky player. The only player not to cause the diver to fall and the foam to fly wins the game.

—description from the publisher

Statera is a double-asymmetric strategy game with a huge amount of replayability.

Statera is a double-asymmetric strategy game with real scales. Its stories give players a lot of replayability and modular game map new experiences for each game. Become a leader of a Statera nation or a powerful God, fight for the territory, balance your believers, gather souls, and experience all of Statera's stories.

You can pick a different story for each game to determine the basic game's setup, get a richer experience, and learn more about the game world's story. By choosing to play for the nations of Statera or their gods you can also select the game's difficulty and the game's length.

In the Statera you will play as one of the nations of Statera or their God. The game is double-asymmetric. The first asymmetry comes from the difference between Gods and Staterans, second, there is an asymmetry between the factions. Some rules and patterns apply to the whole game, some only for Gods or Staterans, and some rules are specific to the faction.

The game is story-based. Each story tells a tale from the land of Statera and through that, it defines a number of players, unique victory conditions, setup, and some small rule adjustments. It basically means that each story, when played, feels like a different game.

The scale rising above the game board is a big part of Statera - the game and the world. The Stories already created for the game, are using the scale to count souls, balance them, lean towards a specific campsite, or take souls away from it. This component is simply crucial to play the game!

The important question is - Are you a brave Stateran, or a mighty god? It is time to lean the scale in your favor!

—description from the publisher

200+ humorous questions for an evening between friends.

Présentation de l'éditeur:

Plus de 200 questions amusantes et humoristiques pour animer soirées et apéritifs entre amis. 200 questions avec un brin d'humour à consommer sans modération entre amis ou en famille  !

Fous rires garantis pour des apéritifs réussis  !

Bones, food bowls, socks and many other treasures can be discovered by you and your friends. Run through the labyrinth to find out which puppies will get rewards, and then shout out "A dog's life" when you find the puppy with his bone.

Be the first of your friends to guess the puppy or to shout "A dog's life" to get all the cards. Hunt together, but make sure you're the winner.

Do you like butterflies? Well, so does the kitten. More so, the little kitten needs you and your friends to help catch the little butterfly so that they can play together.

Gather your friends and follow the butterfly path while it flies from place to place, and guess where it last landed. You'll win cards if you pay attention to the butterfly's flight path and when the kitten catches the butterfly you shout out.

In ã‚¸ã‚§ãƒ ã€€ã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒ©ãƒ³ãƒ–ãƒ« ("Gem Scramble"), a hex-grid board is seeded randomly with square glass tiles in 9 colors.  The center hex is left empty, and each player starts with their token there.  On their turn, a player moves their token in a straight line as far as they'd like, though they may not move onto or past another token.  If there is a glass tile on the destination space, they collect it.

The game ends after a player has collected a certain number of tiles, which varies depending upon the player count.  Points are awarded based upon collecting many tiles of one color, many tiles regardless of color, and for the gold tiles, certain extra scoring is available.  The player with the most points wins.

—user summary

Movie Plotz: Cult Films is the 3rd in the line of standalone Movie Plotz games that allows your group to create hilarious fake movie storylines, then pitch them out loud for maximum laughs. Movie Plotz was designed as a very effective team building event that has evolved into a party game where everyone contributes to the fun.

Players begin with a simple plot (a simple sentence) then draw cards to modify the movie concept. With each draw, players get to redo the pitch and make it even more exciting. In the end, the final plot will be a guaranteed hit!

The game lasts for approximately 20 minutes, until all cards have been played. If you are playing the Last Man Screenwriting variant, the last player standing wins.

This one features 12 cards all based on famous cult films like Pulp Fiction ("Rearrange the order of the scenes."), Office Space ("Add a main character's coworker to the story."), or even The Room ("Make the movie worse.").

—description from the publisher


Each card was also delivered monthly in the 2016 Board Game of the Month Club $5+ packages.

After the world fell and the skies burned
We were left to fight on

Welcome to the world of Five Klicks - Skirmish campaign games for solo and cooperative players, using the tried and tested mechanics of Five Parsecs From Home and Five Leagues From the Borderlands.

In Five Klicks From the Zone you will take a squad into the wasteland, fighting to protect your home from the raiders, mutants and worse that seek to destroy it.


     Well tested combat mechanics that have been enhanced to include pinning and more detailed morale effects, fitting the more military atmosphere of this campaign.
     Experience and Loot system for campaign progression. Watch new recruits become battle hardened veterans..or die somewhere in the burnt wasteland.
     Random event tables to build up the narrative.
     Simple, straight-forward rules that make it easy to set up and play a game on your own.
     Terrain generation table.
     Players select their own campaign victory conditions from a list and earn a bonus for completion.
     Playable with most ranges of modern and science fiction miniatures you may already own. 


This is Chapter 1, offering a complete and replayable campaign game.

—description from the publisher

Navarchus is a miniature tabletop naval warfare game for scale 1:300

In the third century BC Rome was growing in power, but Carthage stood in the way.

The Carthaginians had controlled the Western Mediterranean for more than a century using a fleet of hundreds of war galleys. By coincidence the Romans captured one of these vessels. And because all parts of the vessel were painstakingly numbered Rome could now build its own fleet. Within 6 months Rome possessed a fleet of 120 war galleys.

The war for the Mediterranean could commence...

—description from the publisher

OUTLANDS is a Sci-Fi Spaghetti Western set on the mysterious and deadly planet of Paradise.

The gameplay revolves around an Action/Reaction System that keeps both players in the game. 
The unrestricted rule system allows YOU to 'Level Up' your characters, whilst training new and exciting skills. 
You can make your characters the way YOU want.

Ideally suited for campaign play between a group of friends, the rules allow for one off stand alone games.

All you need to play is this rulebook, 5 models per player (ANY miniatures you already own), a tape measure and a handful of 6 sided dice.

Get ready to take your 1st exciting steps into the OUTLANDS.

The 114 page rulebook include:

     A complete and comprehensive rule system explaining every aspect of OUTLANDS The Game,
     50 Abilities and Special Skills,
     40+ Items of Equipment.
      A revolutionary weapon modification system so that no two weapons are the same.
     Complete rules for creating a 'Spice Hunter' warband.


—description from the publisher

The Lords have returned to Camelot, to reclaim their place at the Round Table! Return to Camelot is a strategic boardgame for 2 players, inspired by the game Chivalry (1887) by George S. Parker. Players take the role of medieval lords, commanding their armies of knights, soldiers, and wizards. Try to conquer your opponent’s castles or capture their lord!

COMPONENTS


     board (8×8)
     20 black pieces with white engraving: 2× lord, 2× wizard, 4× knight, 12× soldier
     carrying case


RULES OVERVIEW (please refer to rulebook)

Players take turns performing actions. On your turn, perform one of the following four actions with one of your pieces (however, if any of your pieces can Capture, the Capture action has priority):


     Capture (by jumping over)
     Deploy (a previously captured piece)
     Move (to adjacent square)
     Jump


TYPES OF PIECES

Soldier: This basic piece can Move, Jump, and Capture.

Knight: You can reveal it to perform an action called “Knight's Charge”.

Wizard: When it Moves, once per game, you can permanently reveal it to cast one of the following two magic spells:

      Divination      
      Teleportation


Lord: This piece can Move, Jump, Capture, and Knight’s Charge.

END OF THE GAME

You win the game if any of the following occur:

      You capture your opponent's lord.
      You occupy one of your opponent’s castles with your lord.
      You occupy both enemy castles with any two of your pieces.


—description from the publisher

Au Son du Clairon is an evolution of the Billy Yank rule system to the Franco-Prussian War.

It also includes an expansion for the Russo-Turkish War of 1877-1878.

Published in French

—description from the publisher

Stat Protocol was designed by medical professionals who still have a sense of humor.  In Stat Protocol, each player is a doctor at a hospital which has been inundated with sick patients!  Players randomly select patients from a deck of cards who each have descriptions of their care, special instructions and length of stay.  Patients are drawn randomly and play is impacted by the event cards and choices that the players (doctors) make with "drug" tokens as well as the number rolled on the dice.  Players may choose to discharge patients or remove them from ICU depending on their game strategy. Don't worry -- you don't need a medical degree to play this game!

—description from the designer

Your ship marooned on a strange, flat planet. The crew sent out in search of vital resources. Lethal dangers found at every turn. Can anyone…

				
				
					Escape from Flat Earth?Dressed in potentially fatal fashion, your Red Suits have beamed down to the Flat Planet. Drawing cards reveals events that create a mission timeline, bestow new card actions to use, or stumble upon attacks that will take your crew if you can’t teleport them out of harm's way.

A narrative-creating card game for fans of sci-fi who should know better than to wear red. And especially for those that don't.

—description from the designer

Wayfarer Tactics is dynamic, modular miniature wargaming system

With these rules, you use models from your collection to enact skirmished, large-scale battles, or party-centered dungeon crawls. Based loosely on our Wayfarer multiverse setting, you can stage your battles in worlds of magic-rich high fantasy, far flung intergalactic sci-fi, or anything in between.


     Any genre! Fantasy, Modern, Steampunk, whatever!
     Any model! Whatever kind of miniatures you collect, you can use them!
     Tell your story! The engine let's you customize your own characters and forces!


—description from back of the book

Astra Imperia is a tabletop wargame.

Expand and explore space around you.

Exploit worlds and exterminate your enemies.

Rules include tactical combat, including ship building and strategic empire building

—description from the publisher

Didactic game produced by an university, to help understand the nature of spin glasses or other complex optimization problems, like organizing a party.
The main target is to choose the favorite orientations of the spins/party guest and their interactions such that each player maximizes the number of spins/guests exhibiting the orientation of the player, respectively.

Via some additional action cards you can increase the number of strategic operations.

Your civilization’s great migration was just beginning when something went wrong. From your place on the bridge, you watched the lead colony ship explode, starting a chain reaction of fire and death that wiped out half the fleet in an instant...

Now, half a galaxy away, you fly under unfamiliar skies. You have no way back to the fleet, no way of knowing if there is even a fleet to return to. You press on alone, lost, in search of a planet to call your own. You will find it or die.

A game of Lost Ship consists of encounters between your ship and alien threats as you leap from system to system in search of a habitable planet. Between battles, you will search for materials, make repairs, care for your pilots, and search for a planet your people can inhabit.

If you find home, you win. If your ship runs out of fuel or is destroyed, you lose, and your civilization dies with you.

—description from the designer

Bill & Ted's Riff in Time combines a mix of awesomely detailed miniatures — from Socrates and Napoleon to former President of the United States of America Abraham Lincoln — with engaging and intuitive rules.

Meeting old friends and a whole bunch of new ones, Bill, Ted, Elizabeth and Joanna must work together to put things right and ensure the future is most excellent!

—description from the publisher

Rebels and Yankees have been designed to introduce new players into wargaming in American Civil War and provide more experienced gamers a simple more relaxed way of enjoying the period without the complexities and depth of match play.
 These rules are not written to provide a purist simulation of the period, but a game with a flavor for the period.

Rebel and Yankees uses 1 base width (BW) to equal 40 yds with 80 men deployed in two ranks. Several bases would make up a regiment unit depending on the regiments size. Base Widths (BW) are used also in the game for movement and range distances. Where players wish to use figures instead of the bases. If that is the case, then for distances use an inch instead of a base width. Calculate dice on number of figures in the front rank instead of the number of bases. For 15mm a base would be around 40mm and in 25/28mm a base width would be around 60mm.

To play the games all you need are six-sided dice (D6), your own models based in a common way between the two forces, terrain to represent the landscape of your battlefield and a ruler.

Polis is a two-player civ-lite game set in the beginning of the conflict between the two major poleis of the 5th century B.C: Athens and the Delian League against Sparta and the Peloponnesian League. The winner will be the Empire with more population and prestige at the end of the game.

Both players must secure their supplies and the routes to five markets to trade with them. Every turn you get goods from a territory where you have population supporting your Empire, but you should feed them.

You can fight to control the territories and siege other polis or you might use your diplomacy to convince a polis to join your league. But polis are proud of their independence so you will have to create some projects to gain prestige needed for your military manoeuvres.

This new edition of Polis has updated revised rules and new art that will enhance your game experience.

—description from the publisher

Sedlec Ossuary, 16th Century AD.

The Black Plague and Hussite Wars have overcrowded the graveyard. Help the Bone Collector, a half-blind monk, by exhuming graves and arranging the skulls inside the crypt.

You are novice monks, competing to create the best arrangement of skulls.

Dig up graves from the graveyard to reveal cards, take cards into your hand to collect skulls, and arrange the cards from your hand into a stack. Whoever better honors the deceased’s last wishes will score more points.

The Bone Collector will then judge each player’s completed stack and declare one as the most exceptional.

—description from the publisher


Released in the June 2020 Board Game of the Month Club $20+ package.

Finalist (top 3) of Button Shy's 18 Card Challenge: Design a game about a real life location.

Ferrum et Gloria is fast play rule for gladiator combat.
Players can play a single gladiator or a gladiators school.
It includes a mini-campaign and rules cover calling to the crowd, effects of fatigue, wounds, many types of attacks...

Ferrum et Gloria è un veloce regolamento per scontri tra gladiatori. Ogni figura rappresenta un combattente con uno specifico repertorio di mosse a seconda del suo addestramento e armamento. Le regole sono basate sulle più recenti ricerche storiche.

Ogni giocatore controlla un singolo gladiatore o un’intera scuola di gladiatori. Un sistema di dadi colorati registra le ferite di ogni combattente.

Ferrum et Gloria contiene regole per:
12 classi gladiatorie;
Scontro tra scuole (mini-campagna);
Tecniche di scherma, opposizione e lotta;
Appello alla folla;
Vari tipi di risultati di combattimento, che consentono di sbilanciare, ferire, disarmare, allontanare o intrappolare in reti;
Simulazione della stanchezza e dell'effetto delle ferite;
Diverse velocità di movimento basate su armamento e stanchezza;
Duelli o combattimenti tra più avversari.

Chef de Char is a beer and pretzel ruleset to simulate tank combats.
Each player represents a tank leader and gives orders to his crew, those are then executed.
—user summary

Chef de Char est une règle 'apéritif' rapide et létale. L'idée n'est pas de faire une règle pointue de simulation mais une règle qui peut, tout à la fois servir à faire découvrir les jeux de stratégie et permettre de passer un bon moment de jeu. Ce n'est pas une règle historique à proprement parlé, l'histoire est présente car la règle intègre les caractéristiques des chars de l'époque.

Cette règle est très simple à prendre ne main et en 2 à trois tours la mécanique est acquise. 
Il y a 3 formats de jeux. Patrouille avec 5 chars par camp, Peloton avec 7 et compagnie avec 12 chars. En fonction du format chaque joueur dispose d'un nombre de point de commandement qu'il dépense pour réaliser un maximum de 3 actions. 
Le joueur est le chef du char actif. Il faut imaginer que le chef de char donne ces ordres à son équipage (le joueur énonce à haute voix ce qu'il va faire), les ordres sont reçus par l'équipage (le joueur dépense ses points de commandement), l'équipage exécute les ordres (le joueur réalise les actions énoncées). 
L'activation d'un char est faite par tirage au sort si bien que les deux joueurs doivent être attentif à ce qui se passe.La stratégie tient alors autant dans le placement sur le terrain, que dans la gestion des points de commandement.

—description from the publisher

Warzoom is a skirmish ruleset for small battles in major conflicts of the first half of the 20th century. 
Scale independent where 1 mini represents 1 man, it offers 3 modes of play:

     fast game
     mini-campaign
     grand-campaign


Warzoom est une règle de jeux d’escarmouche avec figurines destinée à vous faire revivre de grands conflits sur de petites batailles. Adaptés à tous types d’échelles et dotés d’un système innovant d’évolution du terrain de jeu, aucune partie ne ressemblera à la précédente.

Dans ce livre, vous trouverez toutes les règles nécessaires pour rejouer des conflits de la première moitié du 20ème siècle, mais également :

     Des règles de budget pour créer votre propre groupe de combat
     Un système d’expérience simple pour vos soldats
     Des scénarios indépendants ou pour débuter une mini campagne
     Des règles d'actions héroïques pour pimenter les parties !

A Hot Dry Season: Operation Attleboro in War Zone C (AHDS) is an operational-level game dealing with the National Liberation Front (NLF) Dry Season Offensive in the III Corps Tactical Zone (III CTZ) in November 1966 and the subsequent counterattack by forces under the command of Military Assistance Command, Vietnam (MACV).  From the designer’s website:

"To Military Assistance Command-Vietnam (MACV), Operation Attleboro was a meeting engagement in War Zone C that grew into the largest operation involving US Forces conducted in South Vietnam at that time.  To the Central Office for South Vietnam (COSVN), Operation Attleboro was unexpected early contact by a force attempting to conduct an offensive that snowballed into a desperate defense and fighting withdrawal to protect precious logistic and command capabilities essential to their future operations in III Corps Tactical Zone (III CTZ).

MACV grossly underestimated the National Liberation Front’s (NLF) capability to supply their own forces, tactically maneuver them, and evade detection in order to threaten US/Army of the Republic of Vietnam (ARVN) infrastructure and units when operating in close proximity to Peoples’ Liberation Forces of South Vietnam (PLAF – what are popularly known as “Viet Cong Main Force”) base areas in Cambodia.  COSVN grossly underestimated the US’s capability to rapidly reinforce an area of operations using strategic mobility and rapidly employ such reinforcements almost immediately in the field.

MACV underestimated the proclivity of COSVN to use PLAF forces confront and destroy threats to its logistics and supply system.  COSVN erroneously expected US Forces to respond to tactical and operational dilemmas like the ARVN.  To wit, responding to “Ambush and Bait” with dispersed pursuits of the ambushers on multiple axis, thus leaving some pursuing units vulnerable to destruction via “One Slow, Four Quick”.  Both sides were unaware of flaws and gaps in their respective intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) networks, and the murky picture of active operations that would result from a clash of this magnitude, in the trying terrain of War Zone C.  Neither side gained any lasting advantage from Operation Attleboro, though both sides missed opportunities to secure them."

The game’s scale is Company as the primary unit size, day turns and a mile per hex.  AHDS uses a concealed information/movement mechanism for NLF units and a limited information availability mechanism for both sides, and heavily emphasizes Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) capabilities and their impact on revealing concealed/limited information units.  The game uses a movement point system and combat result table mechanisms fires, air defense fire and ground combat.  AHDS has an asymmetric component to its turns, as an Initiative player determines the order of resolution of Fires attacks and missions and then Operations (movement and combat).  Within Operations, interactivity and reactions to phasing player action; reaction moves and hasty attacks may be performed by the non-phasing player as the phasing player’s turn is resolved.  Uncertainty is added to victory and even game end in the campaign by the use of Operational Guidance chits which are selected before set up – neither side may be exactly certain what the other’s priorities are, which impacts victory conditions and player strategy as the game progresses.

AHDS contains 7 scenarios: Introductory, Basic, and Intermediate, ranging from 3 to 10 game turns. The campaign is 25 turns long, but may, through Operational Guidance chit play referred to above, last 30 turns.

AHDS is the first entry in a new series, Campaigns in Vietnam, which features a “Ground-Up Build” system.  While sharing core concepts and “DNA” in resolution of play and movement/combat mechanisms, each title is built from the “Ground-Up” allowing specific tailoring of concepts and rules mechanisms in an attempt to accurately evoke the very different Campaigns fought during the Vietnam War from 1965-1975 and faithfully incorporate the dynamic changes in force structure and composition, weapons and ISR capabilities, specific operational goals and difficulties, and terrain and regional variances unique to Vietnam and the Vietnam War.

Basic Information
Map Scale: 1 mile per Hex
Unit Size: Companies
Time Scale: One day per Turn.
Players: 2
Complexity: Medium-High
Solitaire Suitability: Medium
Play by Email Components: Vassal Module completed, available upon game release.

Game Components and Specifications
Game Map: 22” x 34”    
Game Counters: 840 each .5” Counters (Three Countersheets)
Rulebook: 50 Pages (Color)
Playbook: 50 Pages; contains Scenarios and Campaign, Examples of Play, Designers' Notes, Historical Notes and Tips on Play and Strategy (Color).
Player Aids and Charts: 6 x Double-Sided (Color), 4 x Single Sided (color)
Scenarios and Campaign: Seven Introductory, Basic and Intermediate Scenarios; One Campaign.
Dice: One Ten-Sided Die and Two Six-Sided Dice.

—description from the publisher

Oh, Sheep! is a fast-paced and strategic card game in which players will have to try and get rid of their hand as fast as possible. There are attack, defend and some chaos-mechanics to keep the game engaging and fun for all players.

Monoch is an abstract strategy game in which black and white blocks are combined. The goal is to be the first player to connect both ends of the blocks (Obi) in your color while meeting the building requirements.

Panzer Waffe: Eastern Front 1944 is an card game that recreates a tank battle in 1944. You can enjoy the construction of the tank platoon by the combination of the cards to a deck.

The deck consists of a combination of tank cards such as firepower, defense force, heavy tank and long range, and tactics cards such as precision shooting, ambush, and infantry assault. Because there is a sudden event during the game, it may not win only in a powerful tank. Pull out the platoon's potential and take advantage of tactics to gain victory.

—description from the publisher

You are hungry and can find lots of delicious food in the kitchen. Watch out for the Chef and be aware of the cats in the game! If you don’t get rid of them on time, you will lose points. Rat Attack Party is a challenging card game where you collect as many points as possible in groups of three. But you only grab food from the kitchen workbenches when the Chef isn’t looking.

Are you able to secure enough food from the kitchen to score the most points at the end and win the game?

—description from the publisher

The Pooper Heroes card game is the only game where you can play with a pile of cards that turn into poop in your hand. This can happen to any card if you draw them at the wrong time or if the other players use their Pooper Powers against you. Don’t turn your head away from those smelly cards because you can only win this game if you have the fewest cards in your poop pile at the end.

—description from the designer

The Black Flame Candle has been lit.
Now the Sanderson witches you must outwit;
Or with a wretched evil potion,
A foul spell they’ll set in motion.
Stun the witches and ruin the brew
Before the sun can rise anew!

Disney Hocus Pocus: The Game, based on the 1993 movie "Hocus Pocus", players must work together to ruin the Sanderson Witches’ potion three times before the sun rises. Players hold a hand of ingredients of different types and colors and attempt to match all ingredient types or colors in the cauldron.

Each turn, players ask a question about other players’ hands, referring to the ingredient type or color (but not both). (For example, “Who has blue ingredients?” or “Who has newt saliva?”) They then play a card from their hand into the cauldron and draw back up to three cards, ending their turn.

Some ingredient cards have Binx the cat or a spell book on them. When an ingredient with Binx is played into the cauldron, the active player puts the Binx mover in front of any player. That player then lays their cards down so everyone can see them and keeps them there until Binx is moved. If a spell book is played, the active player draws a card from the Spell deck and resolves the card. Spells generally do something to ruin players’ plans.

If you have cards showing all of one color or all of one object in the cauldron, then you've stunned one of the witches — and you need to stun the witches three times before time runs out! When stunned, a witch cannot cast spells from the deck.

Players also have four “Tricks” to use based on scenes from the movie; each Trick can be used once per game. For example, "Burning Rain of Death" allows you to discard three potion ingredients and draw three new potion ingredients.

A game of observation and speed to know and paly with 50 flags of the world.
Each card has a flag on one side and some information on the nation on the other (the name in 6 languages, the map and the continent). On the back there is also a characteristic unrelated to the nation.
In the middle of the table there are 20 flags and a deck of cards. Each turn, a card is turned and players must take the flags that have the characteristic just turned over: each correct card is set aside. The characteristics to be found are of various types: presence of stripes, stars, crosses or symbols, presence of 2, 3 or 4 colors, presence of a certain color and belonging to a continent.
Whoever wins the most cards wins.

—description from the designer

Battle card game, recreate the greatest air battle in 1940, Britain's RAF versus Germany's Luftwaffe in World War II
Use your battle and tactic cards to out smart your opponent, win dogfights and monitor your squadrons to win battles and ultimately gain air superiority over the fields of Britain. 
Will the few be victorious?

Players will fight 7 battles per round attempting to win the air superiority card.  Whoever wins the most battles this card is moved to their side of the table.  Sequence of play both players must place one of their battle cards face down.  Both players may also play one tactic card face down if applicable. Once done cards are revealed.

Players then work out their final score using a combination of their battle, tactic and event cards, highest score wins.  If a player wins a battle they can change the current event card and also change theirs or their opponents squadrons cards.  Squadron cards will have positive and negative effects on both players.  Event cards will also affect certain cards.

Players can also recreate dogfights in certain situations using a rock, paper, scissor mechanic.  Players must try and get inside their opponents mind, what did they do last round/dogfight etc.

This a pocket card game ideal for travel or to use before or after your main gaming event.  It can also be used to introduce non gamers and children and teach them about history in a quick and fun way.

—description from the designer

The magic show is about to start.

Behind the curtain, it is chaos: the rabbits jump from all sides and the hats roll to the ground!

You have to put all this back in order.

Hurry up! The audience is already getting impatient!

In Magic Rabbit, players will cooperate in a limited time to gather in line rabbits and hats together in an ascending order.

The game design is straightforward. At first, place randomly a Rabbit tile face-down under a Hat tile face up. Then, place Dove tokens, depending of the number of players.

Within 2'30", you will have to rearrange the Rabbits and Hats, so they match their number : Rabbit #1 under Hat #1, from 1 to 9.

At their turn, players have to choose one of these 3 actions, if a pile is not blocked by a Dove token :

     Look at a Rabbit tile in a Rabbit & Hat pile
     Switch 2 Hats between 2 Rabbit & Hat piles
     Switch to Rabbit & Hat tile pile in the line


At the end of their turn, player may also move a Dove token from a pile to another one.

Hidden envelopes will bring some new magic trick to spice up the game difficulty. Envelopes comes in 3 levels and each of then contain several game variants to achieve before opening the next one!

—description from the publisher

Trek 12 is a roll-and-write alpinism game, with progressive difficulty levels and more. To score points, you have to create chains of consecutive numbers from 0 to 12 and areas of a same number.

A game is composed of 19 rolls of two six-sided dice, with one die having values from 1 to 6, and the other from 0 to 5. After each roll, the player must combine both die values to obtain the number to place. You can:


     Add the values of the two dice
     Subtract the value of one die from the other
     Multiply the value of the two dice
     Keep the higher value of the two dice
     Keep the lower value of the two dice


Be careful as you may choose each of these options at most four times during a game. After placing your first number on the game sheet, you must place each subsequent number in a space adjacent to one already filled. You try to make chains and develop areas. Players also have access to several bonus elements to earn during a game.

At the end of a game, numbers that belong to neither a chain nor an area give you minus points. The same applies if you have to place a number greater than 12...

Trek 12 contains three different sheet pads to add narrative with three progressive difficulty levels.

—description from the publisher

Cybermancy is a future-themed card battling game, in which combat takes place in the Virtual Arena, a computer-generated battle-ground where digital warriors fight in bloody, hand-to-hand combat. Players take on the role of Cybermancers, masters of digital combat, who summon virtual avatars to fight for them in the Virtual Arena.

Each player starts the game with a 30 card Summoning Deck, containing the warriors he will summon to the battlefield. Both players draw 7 cards from their Summoning Deck, then draw 5 cards each from the CPU and RAM Power Deck, which will be used to pay the summoning costs of each warrior. Cybermancy uses a unique dual-track power system, in which players decide each round whether to increase the amount of CPU or RAM available for summoning. This allows unlimited flexibility in designing each deck, as well as important tactical choices every round.

Players can attack their opponent's warriors or the enemy avatar itself. When either Cybermancer's health is reduced to zero, the game is over and the surviving Cybermancer wins!

The base game includes complete decks of cards for both the Human and Undead factions. Unlike collectible card games, Cybermancy provides all of the cards right out of the box, and even allows for players to mix and match warriors from different factions. Future expansions will include warrior tribes such as Robots, Aliens, Celestials, Demons, Dinosaurs and more!

The players roll the die to move their 6 discs about the board. The players start with 1 disc on space A of their color. On the roll of an even number another disc is put into play. If a player lands on another disc or a stack of discs, that player captures the stack by putting his or her disc on top of the stack. If a player has captured at least 2 discs, he may return that stack of disks to his home-base (A) to keep them safe. The game ends when there is only one active color of discs left on the board. The winner is the player who captured the most Discs.

—user summary

The scope of Ultra Quick Hockey is much like the other games in the Ultra Quick lineup. With UQ Hockey, we aim to provide you with an extremely quick and accurate method of resolving the final score between two hockey teams. With UQ Hockey you can play out an entire season for a team or a league in rapid fashion. UQ Hockey makes a perfect stand-alone game for season replays. It also functions very well as a complimentary game by resolving the games that don’t particularly interest you in a detailed shot-by-shot game, while you use the detailed game to play out the games that do interest you.

Unlike most quick play games, which only provide a team score, UQ Hockey does offer an optional individual scoring module to allow you to track league leaders in goals and assists. UQ Hockey also features an individual goalie modification for even more realism.

With UQ Hockey, you'll be able to track not only Team wins and losses, but league leaders for Goals scored, assists and GAA.

—description from the publisher

Rubber and Lead is a miniatures car racing game.

Vehicles are armed with a mix of weapons, but at the end of the day, it's all about who gets across the finish line first!

You will need cars, some dice and a track to race on in addition to these rules.

—description from the publisher

A cooperative game where players must explore Mars to find the missing pieces of a martian greenhouse and fix it before all food supplies (potatoes) finish.

The board is a random matrix of hidden cards that the players have to explore moving individually.

Some places hide resources that should be exchanged and combined to create the parts of of greenhouse, but some bad events could happen, like a marsquake that moves the cards, or a meteorites shower that damages some locations.

The players have a limited number of rounds (30) before something unexpected happens, ending the game.

This game was designed at a Global Game Jam.

—description from the designer
